children.value: All the API calls described in this tutorial use the Cloudflare client v4 interface at
. API requests are authenticated in the same manner, using a Cloudflare user's email and API key as the
headers. Your Cloudflare user must be active, verified, and enabled by Cloudflare to use these provisioning specific endpoints.
More details about making Cloudflare API calls can be found in our

Each customer or team that uses Cloudflare should have their own account. This ensures proper security and access of resources. Each account acts as a container of zones and other resources. Depending on your needs, you may even provision multiple accounts for a single customer or team.
To create an account, make a
(string): The name of the account that is displayed in the Cloudflare dashboard.
A successful request will return an HTTP status of
You own the account lifecycle from creation, ongoing management, and finally deletion. To see the newly created account, make a
This endpoint is the same as documented in our
. The same filters can be used for created accounts.
You will get back a list of all the accounts you have created plus any accounts your user already had access to:
If for any reason you need to delete an account you created, call
Account deletion is permanent and will delete any zones or other resources under the account.
A successful request will return the id to confirm the operation:
Now that we have created an account, visualized existing accounts and learned how to delete an account, in the next step we will give another person access to the account.
Learn how to manage external customers access to Cloudflare.
